[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Trait: AptosMoveResolver] [Trait composition vulnerability] Can a malicious implementation provide conflicting behaviors across the multiple supertrait bounds (AggregatorV1Resolver, ConfigStorage, DelayedFieldResolver, ResourceResolver, ResourceGroupResolver, StateStorageView, TableResolver, AsExecutorView, AsResourceGroupView), allowing an attacker to bypass security checks in one trait by exploiting inconsistencies in another? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Trait: AptosMoveResolver] [Type confusion attack] Does the AptosMoveResolver trait enforce that all bound traits operate on the same StateKey type consistently, or can an attacker exploit type coercion between different key types to access unauthorized state or bypass access controls? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Trait: AptosMoveResolver] [State consistency violation] Can implementations of AptosMoveResolver provide different views of the same state through different trait methods (e.g., ResourceResolver vs ResourceGroupResolver), allowing an attacker to exploit time-of-check-time-of-use (TOCTOU) vulnerabilities during transaction execution? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Trait: AptosMoveResolver] [Gas metering bypass] Can an attacker craft transactions that invoke AptosMoveResolver methods in a specific order to bypass gas metering across the different resolver traits, potentially causing DoS by executing expensive operations without proper gas charging? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Trait: AptosMoveResolver] [Trait bound violation] Are there runtime checks to ensure that implementations satisfy all nine supertrait bounds correctly, or can a partially implemented resolver be used during transaction execution, causing undefined behavior or state corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: release_resource_group_cache] [Cache poisoning attack] Can an attacker manipulate the returned HashMap<StateKey, BTreeMap<StructTag, Bytes>> from release_resource_group_cache() to inject malicious resource data that bypasses validation when the cache is released, potentially allowing unauthorized state modifications? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: release_resource_group_cache] [Double-release vulnerability] What happens if release_resource_group_cache() is called multiple times in a transaction execution context - can this lead to use-after-free bugs, double-counting of resources in gas metering, or state inconsistencies? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: release_resource_group_cache] [State key collision] Can an attacker craft StateKeys that collide in the HashMap returned by release_resource_group_cache(), causing resources from one group to overwrite or merge with another group's resources, leading to fund theft or resource duplication? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: release_resource_group_cache] [Cache timing attack] Does release_resource_group_cache() return None vs Some(HashMap) based on gas feature version - can an attacker exploit the timing difference or behavioral change to determine the gas feature version and craft version-specific exploits? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: release_resource_group_cache] [Memory exhaustion] Can an attacker cause release_resource_group_cache() to return an unbounded HashMap with millions of StateKeys and StructTags, causing memory exhaustion and node crashes during VMChangeSet preparation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_group_size] [Integer overflow in size calculation] Can an attacker manipulate resources in a group to cause resource_group_size() to return a ResourceGroupSize that overflows when converted to usize for gas calculations, allowing free or negative-cost operations? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_group_size] [Size manipulation attack] Can an attacker craft a resource group where resource_group_size() returns an incorrect size (too small or too large), allowing them to bypass storage fees or cause incorrect gas metering leading to DoS? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_group_size] [Race condition in size calculation] If resource_group_size() is called concurrently with resource modifications during parallel transaction execution, can this lead to inconsistent size calculations causing state divergence across validators? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_group_size] [Non-existent group handling] What size does resource_group_size() return for a non-existent group_key - can an attacker exploit zero-size returns to avoid paying for resource group creation or cause division-by-zero errors in gas calculations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_group_size] [PartialVMResult error exploitation] Can an attacker trigger specific PartialVMError returns from resource_group_size() to abort transactions at critical points, causing partial state updates or bypassing epilogue gas charging? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_size_in_group] [Individual resource size manipulation] Can an attacker craft a resource with serialized size that differs from what resource_size_in_group() reports, causing gas metering inconsistencies between individual resource charges and group-level charges? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_size_in_group] [Resource tag spoofing] Can an attacker provide a fake resource_tag to resource_size_in_group() that matches a different resource's tag, allowing them to query sizes of protected resources or bypass access controls? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_size_in_group] [Zero-size resource attack] If resource_size_in_group() returns 0 for a resource that actually exists, can this be exploited to create resources without paying storage fees or bypass resource existence checks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_size_in_group] [Size inconsistency across calls] Can an attacker trigger conditions where resource_size_in_group() returns different sizes for the same resource_tag in the same transaction, causing non-deterministic execution across validators? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_size_in_group] [Negative size exploitation] Does the usize return type prevent negative sizes, or can integer underflow in implementations allow negative sizes that cause panics or incorrect gas refunds? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_exists_in_group] [Existence check bypass] Can an attacker exploit timing between resource_exists_in_group() returning false and resource creation to bypass uniqueness constraints, creating duplicate resources within a group? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_exists_in_group] [TOCTOU vulnerability] Can resource_exists_in_group() checks be bypassed through time-of-check-time-of-use races during parallel transaction execution, allowing unauthorized resource access or double-spending? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_exists_in_group] [False negative attack] Can an attacker cause resource_exists_in_group() to incorrectly return false for an existing resource, allowing them to overwrite protected resources or bypass access controls? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_exists_in_group] [False positive attack] Can resource_exists_in_group() incorrectly return true for a non-existent resource, causing transactions to fail or enabling DoS attacks by making resources appear inaccessible? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/move_vm_ext/resolver.rs] [Method: resource_exists_in_group] [Group vs individual resource confusion] Can an attacker exploit differences between resource_exists_in_group() and individual resource existence checks to create phantom resources that exist in one view but not another? (High)
